FacilityName: East Williamson County Water Treatment Plant

Brazos River Authority

East Williamson County Regional Water System





The East Williamson County Regional Water System (EWCRWS) is designed to treat surface water from Granger Lake for public drinking water.  The facility recently completed an expansion and can now treat approximately 12.5 million gallons per day.  Chlorine is used in the system for disinfection purposes and to generate chlorine dioxide.



CHLORINE:

The 1-ton chlorine containers are stored in a newly constructed chemical storage building with forced air ventilation.  The containers are connected to the main header via whip lines.  The main header goes directly into pressure regulators/switchover mechanisms whereby the system goes under vacuum.  The room has a chlorine gas detection alarm system to warn of a chlorine gas leak as well as a ventilation system to draw fresh air in and force air out near the floor.



The chlorine is drawn by vacuum into the chlorinator room where it is mixed with water for process application.  Fresh air is forced into the chlorinator room, with exhaust air going out from the floor level.  The chlorinated water is injected into the process through Vaults 3, 4, and 5.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Authority policies include the need for a written emergency action plan, exercises and reviews of the plan, emergency response training for facility personnel, and coordination with local responders.  In addition, monthly safety inspections are conducted by the Authority's Safety Training Officer.  Risk management consultants from our insurance company are used as resources.



Accidental Release Prevention Program



The chemical storage area is enclosed and equipped with the latest technology to contain and scrub any chemical releases. Plant personnel are trained to handle chemical containers in such a manner as to prevent leaks or spills while connecting or disconnecting containers.  Personnel are also trained to shut down the syst

em by closing the container valve in the event of an emergency or anticipated emergency. 

 



Five-Year Accident History



There were no reportable accidental releases of regulated chemicals in the last five years.



Emergency Response Program



EWCRWS staff have the capability to respond to and mitigate incidental releases of on-site hazardous substances where the substances can be absorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel, as well as responses to releases of hazardous substances where there is minimal potential safety or health hazard (i.e. fire, explosion, or chemical exposure).  If the spill/release is beyond the capability of onsite personnel, the City of Taylor and Williamson County HAZMAT teams will respond by calling 911. Training and exercises are to be conducted periodically. The city and county have conducted a regional WMD terrorism exercise, which included the intentional release of hazardous chemicals. They conduct exercises related to hazardous chemical releases that Brazos River Authority personnel participate in.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



We completed joint training with local first responders and conducted additional internal HAZMAT and chemical safety training for operators, maintenance, and administrative personnel. Security enhancements and procedures have been made since 9-11 and continuous improvements are made as resources become available.
